title: Grade 5
subject: Alternative Content Standards - English Language Arts (2017-)

document.title: ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR GRADE 5: ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTS

E1F2250BCAB24B1CAC7F7C3E74119AF5.description:
Select or create
audio recordings and
visual/tactile displays to
enhance a presentation.

6E8341810C9B4DD9A47188BD5F89026E.description:
The student can choose
a piece of information that is related
to a given topic in preparation for a
writing project.

CCBD1575736F4CFCB3EC1918A96E2CB9.description:
The student can
choose pieces of information that
are related to a given topic in
preparation for a writing project.

8E3A1005CEF145969D9E39DCF6F70AF6.description:
The student can sort
information into categories in
preparation for a writing project.

740599B76CE54F9B9E199A29757CF28D.description:
Gather and sort
relevant information on a
topic from print or digital
sources into given categories.

17C29F7E66D144C8AA66977A98D2D33C.description:
Conduct short
research projects using two
or more sources.

F3E29894B3374D7A962536DE3BE207DD.description:
With guidance and
support from adults, use
technology, including the
Internet, to produce writing
while interacting and
collaborating with others.

88E8E60C472543B3947704EC4A3C9C34.description:
The student can
select labeled pictures that relate to
a given topic.

604FE2EE353443FCACDC4DB5903F6E4B.description:
The student can
select words/phrases that relate to a
given topic.

0065D77439E74E8CAA504BD29AA467F4.description:
The student can
identify/organize/list facts, details, or
other information that relate to a
given topic.

66508D2CCC2B4998BE2FC5684CF689E6.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details

668F2BFA49214D5F961CAF8C49EAC0B7.description: Students can investigate topics and present information.

1E8B4ED209814CE78E54B154C6134045.description:
Use words acquired
through conversations, being
read to, and during shared
reading activities including
domain-specific words.

58B86F700DBD454E850EA6D84CEDA373.description:
The student can identify
the correct use of language to
communicate effectively with
familiar people (e.g., sharing
information, responding to
greetings, being polite, and making
simple requests, etc.).

B5015CC1B92F441E8582541FD0CFBA20.description:
The student can use
language to communicate
effectively with a variety of
audiences and for different
purposes (e.g., asking questions,
sharing information, responding to
greetings, using polite expressions,
using appropriate body language).

7C08938E2AAB4AA7A0185289517A41A5.description:
The student can use
language effectively to communicate
with peers and adults (e.g., asking
and answering questions, initiating
conversations, sharing information,
and making requests).

090BB7DB5C5A4E5FBCEDB18EB94E34A5.description:
Use language to
achieve desired meaning
when communicating.

5AC396AC8E4947C1A2D63D211A64DCCE.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions
of Standard English.

24DAD843BEE3498CB6430DD4CB58BFAA.description:
The student can identify
correct usage of singular/plural
nouns when communicating.

C85078C4B3BE4E538719D414E0382F26.description:
The student can
identify correct usage of simple
grammatical structures (e.g.,
singular/plural nouns, appropriate
pronouns, verbs) when
communicating.

286D56117161497E8CDB0D8CD2C88B0C.description:
The student can identify
the correct usage of grammatical
structures, including (but not limited
to) frequently occurring past tense
irregular verbs (e.g., went, sat, ate,
told) and/or conjunctions (and, but,
or, for, because).

1F79A0CFBDCE4B48A899129A9612C2C1.description:
Demonstrate
Standard English grammar
and usage when
communicating.

73DAFBA11CB540779DA3EF98F036C1AA.description:
Differentiate
between contexts that
require formal and informal
communication.

A70C8E22D2634D53AFA1F6BD72069FD3.description:
Report on a
familiar topic or text or
present an opinion including
related facts.

02E563A9CE8D4B70B69F5CE67D6277C4.description:
Identify the
reasons and evidence
supporting a specific point.

B1FFE5D91B73453DB360ADD49F273E73.description:
The student can select
one or more details from
information presented orally or
through other media.

E97E09DCDCC347F49CB698E822FC86C0.description:
The student can
answer questions about information
presented orally or through other
media, including (but not limited to)
the main idea of the presentation.

A17B4CBB17DF4089A9A5521FA1EFC7CF.description:
The student can
identify/state the main idea of a text
presented orally or through other
media and/or identify a supporting
reason for a specific point.

B2D119D7AC794E94A0F904370F4D82A8.description:
Identify the
explicitly stated main idea of
a text presented orally or
through other media.

76E7AD1A4B504186853DDA6384D84C2E.description: Students can communicate for a range of purposes and audiences.

09816930EB8B4F4D9F6AE2B751438307.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions
of Standard English.

95C8AA69DF004169B8AC4607CB533151.description:
Use information
from literary and
informational text to support
writing.

D6DF0D337E96493484A126D0AC5FEAFA.description:
With guidance and
support from adults and
peers, plan before writing
and revise own writing.

356BC941E01348618E072C625251CD1E.description:
Produce writing
that is appropriate for an
explicitly stated task or
purpose.

37028B0155BA4AF098A626F96DC29F26.description:
The student can
indicate when something happened
(before or after) while preparing to
write/communicate about an event
or personal experience.

782EA024883246C29AAADA49ED5BED87.description:
The student can
order two details/happenings while
preparing to write/communicate
about an event or personal
experience.

E1A38BFC6FFD4C20A46D649773F27535.description:
The student can
write/draw/dictate about an event or
personal experience, using two or
more actions/happenings in
sequence.

C26813E981E4408EB18FD5BCE3DE373E.description:
Write about
events or personal
experiences

B33E96FAB1DC4D3483C82035D96A19A6.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details

51D6C58FE4A040A8BE9FF9167F8B6687.description:
The student can select a
word or labeled picture that expresses
an opinion about a given topic or text.

4F8F1C54B1C14D7C9FE8F038E2526DF3.description:
The student can
write/draw/dictate an opinion
about a given topic or text.

859D890CD51E42A69BC11902D46A593C.description:
The student can
write/draw/dictate an opinion about
a given topic or text and provide one
reason to support it.

41354A496AA14D2BAEA379373C792576.description:
Write opinions
about topics or text.

E2D22B53350641A0AFC180BB995F4642.description: Students can produce writing for a range of purposes and audiences.

F69F4BE0497F4475B3483E9FBAD7A0BF.description:
The student can identify
a word with the same meaning as a
target word that appears in a one- to
two-sentence text.

843F5D1C149342F9B6E34F33657EB2B9.description:
The student can
identify a word with the same
meaning as the target word that
appears in a paragraph of text.

789DFA88E4CD4DAAB2F518DB4BCFAA47.description:
The student can
demonstrate understanding of the
meaning of words used in context,
including (but not limited to)
synonyms.

EEED2B68568D4E5384E30981C45B8373.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationship and use

FE63A1749A2F4BDEB82EDB8560DD79A2.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationship and use

0086E92CA2FD4148B5CA6297B69A879C.description:
The student can use
cues to recognize the meaning of
familiar words when paired with
pictures and/or objects.

25E2C434B9274DDC897932992516CD02.description:
The student can use
context clues to determine the
meaning of familiar words paired
with pictures and/or objects.

C580B3BB30884D13889044872BEB4929.description:
The student can use
context as a clue to guide selection of
a word or words that best completes
a sentence.

BB49613AFF5847D4B7C2CD4E40EC50C8.description:
Use letter-sound
knowledge to read words

387A400E9F014954945DEC16B042886E.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of text while
actively engaged in shared
reading of history/social
studies, science, and technical
texts.

1484EAD820FD4FCF939EEB1B04B2868D.description:
Compare and
contrast details gained from
two texts on the same topic.

E0B8F4A7547440A387501DF21F839AC1.description:
Identify the
relationship between a
specific point and supporting
reasons in an informational
text.

220B5D497ECD4199A090B85FA2C15A88.description:
The student can identify
a picture or title that goes with a
particular informational text (e.g.,
communication system, poster,
recipe, etc.).

A428C9EA25D24F15A60B64A9586F9FA0.description:
The student can use
text features (illustrations, pictures,
graphics, labels, lists, charts, graphs,
tables, etc.) to answer questions
about informational text.

75813114A5644634AD273BAD6B1B7BD3.description:
The student can use
text features (bold, italics, and
underlined text; headings; captions;
graphics; illustrations; text boxes;
tables; glossaries, etc.) to locate
information within informational text
and/or answer questions about the
text.

9312D41B30854F40B3F6E190DA6187D1.description:
Locate information
in print or digital sources.

7E54C420BCFA4D2A8D5D1029BD62D78B.description:
Compare two
books on the same topic.

F843840F12BB4EFDAD16DA23A301BD32.description:
The student can identify
different types of informational texts
(e.g., recipes, books, posters,
calendars, etc.).

72B3E2DC3724493D8DB781E34B93EFEF.description:
The student can
identify a variety of informational
texts and/or associate a text with its
purpose (e.g., dictionaries define
words, newspapers provide
information on events, calendars
provide dates, schedules provide
times, etc.).

7BF1856E00A04D4D9581EA110F660968.description:
The student can
determine the purpose of an
informational text (e.g., to tell about
events, provide information, give
directions, etc.).

EA797DA56B4D40BCB6914D06BAC9A95F.description:
Determine if a text
tells about events, gives
directions, or provides
information on a topic.

B61AA17E304A41EBA8BEFBFC16CFC12C.description:
Determine the
meanings of domain-specific
words and phrases.

4C98F15D95B34A10A57F67C13B40B52B.description:
The student can identify
what is the same between two
individuals or two locations with a
one- to two-sentence informational
text.

E55A59919F454F15B687E70736EFBC05.description:
The student can
identify what is the same between
two individuals, two locations, or
two events within a paragraph of an
informational text.

57710EF5612E40348F32173C2B4109E3.description:
The student can
identify similarities between
individuals, events, or ideas in
informational text.

04D2EF6A24B7409F9BA156F7BBE6B823.description:
Compare two
individuals, events, or ideas
in a text.

E46CF35C6AA541FDA2B6BC227F37F67E.description:
The student can identify
the topic of a one- to two-sentence
informational text.

B06578C50A88424280622B7F97F130BC.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of a one-paragraph informational text.

3257D6EBA650481183CFAB6A9E4141DB.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of a multi-paragraph informational text in
which the main idea is not explicitly
stated.

945ADD7EC4F848D88F4E1022D9F12ED8.description:
Identify the main
idea of a text when it is not
explicitly stated.

5944809A7FBA4AB2AEB94226E754992A.description:
The student can answer
simple who, what, where, or when
questions about short informational
texts.

D7A2661F786A47009B3C1E3A00A584A8.description:
The student can use
details in an informational text to
answer basic questions about the
text.

C8D4002E9FD448E3B84349A76CC7F5D2.description:
The student can use
details from informational text to
answer questions about the text.

69D45C3BFD3E4891B21654494FC49E43.description:
Identify words in
the text to answer a question
about explicit information.

BFFEC1AFB1FA43B9A589DD49A8EBE974.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of text while
engaged in individual or
group reading of stories,
dramas, and poems.

E73CAA71892C4D55A30F72A9CB4C0AE6.description:
Compare stories,
myths, or texts with similar
topics or themes.

B7AD573BE05541DA848D6556965A12E1.description:
Identify
illustrations, tactual or
multimedia elements that
add to understanding of a
text.

EB81D8F5749C4EE8B245D1BC73C141DE.description:
The student can identify
who is telling the story/speaking
when given two choices.

194735AD901A48A7B1BE9B29AA9786C0.description:
The student can
identify what the narrator/speaker
believes during a story/speech.

6AF20B5A39C648C4B032B67109420C39.description:
The student can
identify the narrator’s/speaker’s
point of view (i.e., what he/she
thinks or feels about the topic of the
text/speech).

6E8424F3017E42F59F7DDD167CACC70B.description:
Determine the
point of view of the
narrator.

5E6D24729B1D4F50A529EFE18B7875B0.description:
The student can use
pictures and/or words to indicate
what happened first or last in a short
narrative text.

27F529D7240448BABB978DB7DC8761C1.description:
The student can use
pictures or phrases to show what
happens at the beginning, middle,
and end of a narrative text.

CCBEFB3D08084059B6F1F7434242A132.description:
The student can
identify an element (e.g., character,
setting, or event) of a narrative text
that changes from beginning to end.

168DB00849E8408EA8CA22482C07063A.description:
Identify a story
element that undergoes
change from beginning to
end.

7A7135369EDD4EA7A36F0F9DA42E7F7F.description:
Determine the
intended meaning of multi-meaning words in a text.

0309C942802E405E9126AC01C0AAA0B4.description:
The student can identify
what is the same between two
characters when given a visual model
to match.

7DB1270C164C485A932504D9B09796E6.description:
The student can
identify what is the same between
two characters within a paragraph of
a narrative text.

3A3344099216499B829253E75DE18969.description:
The student can
compare two characters in a
narrative text.

16D4552E21814A9B80429FDC182D1047.description:
Compare two
characters in a familiar story.

63A8973F69DB44CC93D5B34F4EA9083D.description:
The student can identify
the main idea of a one- to two-sentence narrative text.

ADF42FB957AA4E4887AB97AC878693FC.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of a one-paragraph narrative text.

D8CD34938BA04C2B9C9CC636C3CF2EEF.description:
The student can
identify the theme or main idea of a
multi-paragraph narrative text.

D3E0C9F7FC854F2F98FB9A8D5A1ED04A.description:
Identify the
central idea or theme of a
story, drama or poem.

CD74F39268564346B3FB989329C46A9C.description:
The student can answer
simple who, what, where or when
questions about narrative text.

E9AAEF564C294C40863AA189FC54B246.description:
The student can
answer questions about basic
elements in a narrative text (e.g.,
characters’ names, settings, and
specific events).

013D4303F79D415892DFC74B53ECF9FE.description:
The student can use
details, including (but not limited to)
specific words from the text, to
answer questions about narrative
text.

81EBA3367BA44D599C54E96BE6D43C08.description:
Identify words in
the text to answer a
question about explicit
information.

BAF6ED9AA15446CC9853EA7983A7D6E4.description: Students can comprehend text in increasingly complex ways.
